Since the initial exposure to the great Dharma, the wind of transformation was not complete. Seng Hui wanted to make the Way flourish in the Jiang Huai region and establish a monastery. He then took his staff and traveled east.
In the years of the Wu Red Sparrow era, he arrived in Jianye.
He immediately built a thatched hut, set up an image, and practiced the Way.
At that time, there were no monks.
Suspecting him of being a deviant,
the officials reported it to Sun Quan.
He summoned and questioned him.
What spiritual evidence do you have? Why do you alone change your appearance?
Hui said:
Since the Tathagata's passing, it has been over a thousand years.
His remaining bones are known as sarira in the world.
They manifest spiritual light everywhere.
In the past, when King Asoka ruled Jambudvipa,
he built 84,000 jeweled stupas.
The establishment of stupas and temples is to show the remaining teachings.
Quan considered it boastful.
He said:
If you can obtain sarira, I will build a stupa for you.
Hui then filled a bottle with water, burned incense, and made an offering.
After twenty-one days, it was still not seen, and everyone was shaken with fear.
When it reached the fifth watch,
suddenly a loud sound was heard from inside the bottle.
Hui went to see for himself,
and indeed he obtained the relic.
The next morning, he presented it to Sun Quan.
The entire court gathered to observe.
The five-colored light and flames illuminated above the bottle.
Sun Quan himself held the bottle and poured it onto a bronze plate.
Where the relic struck, the plate immediately shattered.
Sun Quan was greatly startled and said,
This is an auspicious sign!
Hui further said,
The majestic spiritual power of the relic is not just its luminous appearance.
It cannot be burned by the fire at the end of the eon,
and it cannot be crushed by a vajra hammer.
Sun Quan ordered a test of it. Hui made another vow, saying,
The Dharma cloud is about to cover, and the people look up to the grace.
I wish you would further manifest a spiritual manifestation to widely show its majestic spiritual power.
He then placed the relic on an iron anvil
and ordered a strong man to strike it with a hammer.
The anvil and hammer both sank in.
The relics were undamaged.
Quan greatly admired and served them.
He immediately built a stupa.
Because it was the first Buddhist temple, it was called Jianchu Temple.
He named the area where it was located Buddha Grove.
Thus, the great Dharma in Jiangzuo was established through Hui's power.
When Sun Hao was in power, his laws were harsh and tyrannical, and he abolished licentious sacrifices.
He also wanted to destroy Buddhist monasteries.
The ministers all said:
The power of the Buddha is not the same as other gods.
When Kang Hui manifested spiritual responses, the great emperor founded the monastery.
If we now lightly destroy it, we fear it will bring misfortune in the future.
Hao's intention was not yet clear.
He sent Zhang Yu to the monastery to question Hui.
From dawn to dusk, Yu was unable to defeat him.
He then asked to withdraw.
Hui saw him out the gate.
At that time, there was a licentious shrine next to the monastery.
Yu also criticized, saying:
Since the profound teachings have been believed,
why is it that these people are not reformed?
Hui said:
Thunder and lightning strike, but the deaf do not hear.
How can the sound be so insignificant?
What is valuable is in understanding the principle.
When there is understanding of the principle, the myriad things are all connected.
If it is not the right person, it is like a house divided.
Yu returned and sighed, The talent and wisdom of the assembly are not something I can fathom. I humbly wish
that the imperial court would personally examine it.
Hao gathered the court officials and welcomed the assembly with carriages and horses.
When the assembly was seated,
Hao asked,
What are the teachings of Buddhism about the retribution of good and evil?
What is it?
Hui replied,
When a wise ruler instructs the world with filial piety and kindness, then red-crested birds soar and old men are seen.
When benevolent virtue nurtures beings, then sweet springs gush forth and auspicious seedlings grow.
Since good has signs, evil can also be verified.
Therefore, if one does evil in secret, ghosts can punish it.
If one does evil in the open, people can kill it.
The Book of Poetry says, 'Seeking blessings does not turn back.'
The Book of Changes says, 'Accumulating goodness brings blessings.'
Although this is the strict teaching of the Confucian classics,
it is also the clear admonition of Buddhism.
Hao said,
If so, then the teachings of the Duke of Zhou and Confucius have already been practiced.
What need is there for Buddhism?
Hui said:
What the Duke of Zhou and Confucius taught is to briefly show the world.
The teachings of the Buddha are profound and extensively clarify cause and effect.
Therefore, if one does evil, there will be eternal suffering in hell.
If one cultivates goodness, one will long enjoy peace and happiness in the heavenly palaces.
Using this to illustrate and encourage,
is it not also great?
Hao was unable to refute him.
He consulted about the principles of sin and blessings.
Hui explained them for him.
The words were very concise and essential. Hao, who originally had talent and learning, was delighted and greatly pleased.
He requested to read the precepts for monks.
Hui considered the precepts to be secret and not to be lightly proclaimed.
He then took the one hundred and thirty-five vows of the Bodhisattva's Fundamental Practices.
He divided them into two hundred and fifty matters.
He held them to correspond to the two hundred and fifty precepts for fully ordained monks.
He used them to present to Hao.
Hao saw that the practices of the Buddhas, whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, were all vows to enable sentient beings to attain peace and happiness.
He was doubly delighted.
He then requested to receive the five precepts from Hui.
He then further renovated the Hui Temple.
He proclaimed it to the imperial clan, and none did not have faith and reverence.
Hui was in the Wu court.
He quickly expounded the true Dharma, praying for the multitude.
He translated many sutras at Jianchu Temple.
Many lost their originals.
As shown separately.
He also wrote commentaries on various sutras and prefaces.
They all wonderfully capture the correct essence, and the meaning and principles are harmonious.
The sutras he annotated, such as Anban Shouyi, Fajing, and Daoshu,
Are all seen in the catalog. He also transmitted Sanskrit chanting.
His voice was very gentle, mournful, and melodious.
Even today, people imitate it.
In the fourth month of the fourth year of Tianji in Wu,
Hao surrendered to Jin.
Hui passed away in the ninth month.
